author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Climate-Friendly Meat? Regulators Tighten Scrutiny of Label Buzzwords.
description: The new guidelines from the Agriculture Department encourage third-party assessments of environment-related claims, which have come under fire.
content: Climate-smart. Regeneratively grown. Sustainable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Angell
title: Do You Have a Case of the ‘September Scaries’?
description: Late August can be a time of sleepy summer pleasures — and pit-in-the-stomach dread for what’s coming after Labor Day. Here’s how to manage all the feelings.
content: If January is the Monday of the calendar year, then summer is clearly its weekend — June is its Friday, July its Saturday and August its lazy, delicious, fretful Sunday. Which is why so many of us currently find ourselves in the grips of the “September Scaries.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Investigation Into Yacht That Sank Off Sicily Broadens
description: Prosecutors are looking into the actions of two other crew members in connection with the sinking of the luxury yacht Bayesian, which caused the deaths of seven people.
content: Prosecutors in Sicily have broadened their investigation into the sinking of the luxury yacht, the Bayesian, and are now looking into the actions of two more crew members, their lawyer said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Where Does Biden’s Student Loan Debt Plan Stand? Here’s What to Know.
description: The Supreme Court refused to allow a key part of President Biden’s student debt plan to move forward. Here’s what’s left of it, and who could still benefit.
content: President Biden’s latest effort to wipe out student loan debt for millions of Americans is in jeopardy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: Three Restaurants Where You Don’t Have to Shout
description: The trick is to avoid restaurants that are completely vibeless. It can be done.
content: My parents will never let me forget the time I took them to Sushi Samba (R.I.P.) — a cavernous carnival of a restaurant so loud that, after a few minutes of attempted conversation, we basically all gave up. I think about that whenever I field recommendation requests (my favorite game!), because the most common one is a plea for quiet restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Colorado to Relocate Gray Wolves After Reports of Livestock Attacks
description: The plan, which comes less than a year after the wolves were released in the area, is potentially a setback for the state’s ambitious reintroduction program, experts say.
content: Less than nine months after the first gray wolves were released into the wild in Colorado  amid widespread attention as part of an ambitious reintroduction program, officials are now scrambling to capture and move the state’s first breeding pack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Telluride Film Festival Embraces a Political and Topical Lineup
description: The films partly reflect the business realities of Hollywood, which is still grappling with the aftereffects of the writers’ and actors’ strikes last year.
content: As luck would have it, the documentary filmmaker Matt Tyrnauer was recording a conversation with James Carville, the longtime political analyst and subject of Mr. Tyrnauer’s new movie, in May 2023 when a national poll revealed that likely voters favored former President Donald J. Trump over President Biden by seven percentage points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong Editors Convicted of Sedition in Blow to Press Freedom
description: The editors said they published stories in the public interest. A judge ruled they were guilty of a crime against national security.
content: The two veterans of Hong Kong’s long boisterous news media scene didn’t shy away from publishing pro-democracy voices on their Stand News site, even as China cranked up its national security clampdown to silence critics in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Son of Spanish Actor Is Convicted of Murdering and Dismembering Surgeon in Thailand
description: Daniel Sancho Bronchalo was sentenced to life imprisonment after a court in Koh Samui ruled that he was guilty of murdering Edwin Arrieta Arteaga last year.
content: A court in Thailand on Thursday sentenced Daniel Sancho Bronchalo, the son of the Spanish actor Rodolfo Sancho, to life in prison after finding him guilty of murdering a Colombian surgeon and dismembering his body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Homeless Shelters That Prioritize ‘the Three Ps’ — Especially Privacy
description: Prefabricated modular campuses in Northern California are offering comforts that may help keep people off the streets — with pets, possessions and private space in mind.
content: Even before the pandemic, some large homeless shelters in and around San Francisco were not cutting it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Namibia, Facing Drought, Plans to Kill Elephants for Meat
description: The Southern African country plans to butcher over 700 wild animals, including 83 elephants and 300 zebras, to feed people and, it hopes, cut down on dangerous cross-species encounters.
content: The Southern African nation of Namibia is planning to butcher hundreds of its most majestic animals to feed some of the 1.4 million people — nearly half the country — who are in a hunger crisis amid the worst drought in a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: A Father’s Search for a Son Who Didn’t Want to Be Found
description: Bob Garrison was determined to rescue his son from the streets. The path was more difficult than he had imagined.
content: The trip had been a long shot. Bob Garrison reminded himself of that as he stood on a pier a thousand miles from home. Behind him lay the tile-roofed beach town of San Clemente, Calif., his last stop. Before him stretched the Pacific Ocean, immense and unbound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Seeking Mavis Beacon’ Review: A Search for a Black Luminary
description: Two digital sleuths set out to find the woman who lent her image to computer software in this scattered documentary.
content: Upon the release of the 2017 podcast “Missing Richard Simmons,” the host Dan Taberski said that he didn’t want to tell the story in a first-person documentary, because that sort of nonfiction film — the kind that stars the storyteller — is hard to pull off without it seeming self-indulgent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Postal Service Overhaul Runs Into Challenges
description: Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general, defended the 10-year plan to stabilize the agency’s finances, although he acknowledged that officials had faced initial challenges.
content: More than three years ago, the U.S. Postal Service unveiled a sweeping 10-year plan meant to steer the organization out of a financial crisis. The plan, which included consolidating locations, raising prices and lengthening promised delivery times, was meant to stabilize an agency that had lost $87 billion over the past 14 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: How to Watch the Harris-Walz Interview
description: The interview on Thursday will offer a rare unscripted look at Vice President Kamala Harris, who will be joined by her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz.
content: An interview with Vice President Kamala Harris, who has taken few questions from reporters since President Biden ended his re-election campaign last month, will be broadcast on CNN on Thursday night, in her first extended interview as the Democratic presidential nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín and Sara Ruberg
title: Backpage Founder Gets Five Years in Case That Shut Down Website
description: Michael Lacey, 76, co-founded the website that became known for its ads for prostitution. He was convicted on a money laundering charge in a case that included accusations of sex trafficking.
content: A founder of the shuttered classified advertising website Backpage was sentenced on Wednesday to five years in federal prison in connection with a sweeping case that led to the closing of the website and accusations against its executives that they promoted sex trafficking, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Can China Tech Find a Home in Silicon Valley?
description: Entrepreneurs and venture capitalists are setting up firms across the Pacific, only to find that any investment with Chinese ties is a hard sell.
content: One Saturday evening in late July, more than 100 people attended an elaborate party in the lush garden of a mansion in Silicon Valley. The host was David Wei, a former chief executive of Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant, and now a venture capital investor. Guests, most dressed in white, were offered Panama hats as the bright California sun set and models walked a catwalk between large round tables covered with white cloths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘The Falling Star’ Review: A Dark Story in Meticulous Wrapping
description: A series of mishaps befall an activist-turned-bartender in a visually rich but shallow Belgian film.
content: “The Falling Star” works best if you watch it with the same eyes through which you’d watch a ballet, albeit a slapsticky one. The story it tells is dark, but the way in which it’s told is lightly comedic, more dependent on images and movement than character and plot. That the film’s directors, Dominique Abel and Fiona Gordon, both got their start (and met each other) as clowns is no surprise. They star here, too: Gordon as Fiona, a bereaved mother who is also a private eye; and Abel as two characters, an activist-turned-bartender, Boris, and his depressed doppelgänger, Dom, who is also Fiona’s ex-husband.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Lozada and Jillian Weinberger
title: Kamala Harris Wrote Two Books. They Paint Different Pictures.
description: Carlos Lozada on the vice president’s evolving views on criminal justice.
content: Kamala Harris has made her time as a prosecutor central to her presidential pitch. In this audio essay, Carlos Lozada, a Times Opinion columnist and host of “Matter of Opinion,” examines Harris’s two memoirs, reflects on how her criminal justice message has changed and explores what that may reveal about her candidacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Dueling Ramones Heirs Fight Over the Punk Band’s Legacy
description: The brother of Joey Ramone and the widow of Johnny Ramone, who each control half of the band’s intellectual property rights, have filed lawsuits against each other.
content: Years of disputes over control of the legacy of the Ramones escalated this month when the brother of Joey Ramone sued the widow of Johnny Ramone, accusing her of trademark infringement, trademark dilution and breach of contract.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Specter
title: For Solo Explorers, a Solitude-Friendly ‘Paradise’ Amid the Crowds
description: More architects and urban planners are designing parks, airport lounges, museums and other public spaces that make lone visitors feel at ease.
content: Public space, by definition, is meant to be shared. So why are architects throughout the world designing parks, airport lounges, museums, shops and other communal areas to accommodate the lone individual?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Adam Rasgon, Cecilia Kang, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Israel Steps Up West Bank Raids, and Trump’s Arlington Incident
description: Plus, the Paralympics begin in Paris.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
description: Debuts by Joana Mallwitz and Aigul Akhmetshina, as well as the Juilliard String Quartet’s vintage Schoenberg, are among the highlights.
content: The pianist Isata Kanneh-Mason has the happy habit of making musically enjoyable albums that are also uncommonly well thought through. Her first solo release for Decca was an important survey of the works of Clara Schumann; her second, “Summertime,” took in Samuel Coleridge-Taylor and Amy Beach, as well as George Gershwin and Samuel Barber; a third, “Childhood Tales,” featured a rare account of Ernst von Dohnanyi’s “Variations on a Nursery Song.” Each was solidly played, and each made for fulfilling listening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Cade Metz
title: OpenAI in Talks for Deal That Would Value Company at $100 Billion
description: While some young A.I. companies have struggled to compete with the tech industry’s giants, OpenAI has been rapidly expanding.
content: OpenAI is in talks to complete a deal that would value the company at $100 billion or more, which would be about a $20 billion increase from its valuation eight months ago, according to two people with knowledge of the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: avaricious
description: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word avaricious has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 12 in the Opinion essay “A Chance for Hope in Haiti’s Latest Crisis” by Lydia Polgreen:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and David Pierson
title: Top Biden Aide Holds Rare Talks With Chinese Military General
description: Jake Sullivan also met with China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, who said the United States should “find a correct way for the two major countries to get along.”
content: The White House national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, met on Thursday with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and held rare talks with a top Chinese military official in a sign that the two countries are communicating at senior levels despite tensions over the South China Sea and Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Ben Casselman, Mooj Zadie, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Eric Krupke, Clare Toeniskoetter, Lisa Chow, Brendan Klinkenberg, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: Why Tipping Is Everywhere
description: In the United States, many say tipping is expected in more places these days. Here’s how tipping culture exploded.
content: Tipping, once contained to certain corners of the economy, has exploded, creating confusion and angst. Now, it is even becoming an issue in the U.S. presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
description: This month’s picks involve a high-wire showman, a self-dramatizing tennis star and a Brazilian director reflecting on his past.
content: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Dillon
title: Waiting, and Waiting, and More Waiting for a Lover to Leave His Wife
description: The Norwegian author Vigdis Hjorth’s latest novel to be translated into English, “If Only,” follows a decade-long affair between two married writers.
content: Youthful heartbreak notwithstanding, I suppose it must be possible to get through life without ever having confronted love or desire as truly capsizing events — as mental, moral or practical ruin. Some of us manage to consign such interludes to the list of a life’s wrong turns: the “bad place” in which you found yourself, the lure of a “narcissist,” the deranging effects of misplaced longing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Why an Asian American Reporter Wanted to Write About Romance
description: Hollywood has portrayed Asian American men in unflattering ways for decades. One Culture reporter aimed to bring the uncomfortable conversations out of group chats, and into The Times.
content: There is a scene in the 2023 film “Past Lives” in which Nora Moon, the protagonist, calls Hae Sung Jung, her childhood friend, “really masculine, in this way I think is so Korean.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Push for Gender Equality in E.U.’s Top Roles Looks Set to Fall Short
description: Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president, asked member countries to nominate both men and women for commission roles.
content: The European Union has presented itself as a champion for promoting gender equality, adopting rules requiring companies to increase the number of women on their boards and pushing employers to address the gender pay gap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Naked Emperors and Crypto Campaign Cash
description: Why a mostly useless industry dominates corporate political spending.
content: Once upon a time there was an emperor who loved being fashion-forward. So he was receptive to some fast-talking tailors who promised to make him a suit out of new, high-technology fabric — a suit so comfortable that it would feel as if he were wearing nothing at all. “Fortune favors the brave,” they told him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,168
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 30, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Jack Nicas
title: Brazil Threatens to Ban Elon Musk’s X
description: The country’s Supreme Court gave the service 24 hours to name a legal representative in Brazil or face suspension.
content: Brazil’s Supreme Court on Wednesday gave Elon Musk 24 hours to name a legal representative for X in Brazil or face a ban of his social network across the nation of 200 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 446
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Aug. 30, 2024.
content: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level and if you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron, Maggie Haberman and Eric Schmitt
title: Trump Aide ‘Abruptly Pushed Aside’ an Arlington Cemetery Official, the Army Says
description: The statement from the Army is the first detailed description of an altercation that took place on Monday, as Mr. Trump appeared for a wreath-laying ceremony.
content: The Army on Thursday defended an official at Arlington National Cemetery who was physically pushed by a member of former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign after the official sought to stop the campaign from filming in a heavily restricted area of the cemetery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Thomas Fuller
title: Toll Reaches 17 Dead in Israel’s West Bank Raid, Including a Militant Commander
description: The operation is the largest Israeli military incursion in over a year into the West Bank, which has become a third front in a conflict also being fought in Gaza and along the border with Lebanon.
content: Israel’s military stormed a mosque in the occupied West Bank on Thursday, where it said weapons were being stored, and engaged in gun battles that left at least five Palestinians dead, including a young militant commander who Israel says was responsible for attacks against Israeli civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: ‘Joy’ Is a Euphemism for a Word No One Wants to Say Out Loud
description: People who are pinning all their hopes on one attribute are going to be disappointed — again.
content: I hate to rain on the parade, but there is something fake about this business of the joy — and not just joy but JOY, as Oprah told us last week — surrounding the elevation of Kamala Harris. The problem is that no one is talking about what the joy is really based on and how it could let us down in the end.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Fast Food for a Short but Sweet Summer in the Casse-Croûtes
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 29, 2024.
content: “You can taste the sea. We are from Sicily, so we are used to good, fresh seafood.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Eric Schmitt and Edward Wong
title: Inside the Frantic U.S. Efforts to Contain a Mideast Disaster
description: A bigger disaster may have been avoided, even as the region continues to teeter on the brink of wider war.
content: As Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken flew to Mongolia on July 31, his mind was on events far away, in the Middle East.  Hours earlier, Israel had assassinated a top Hamas leader in Tehran, and Iranian officials were vowing retaliation for the murder of a close ally on their soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: In Georgia, Local Officials Express Frustration Over New Election Rules
description: The State Election Board recently approved procedures that the people who run elections across the state said would make the process less secure and their jobs more difficult.
content: The people who run elections in Georgia are angry and frustrated over new state rules that they say will make the process less secure and their jobs more difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Cruise Ship Worker Sentenced to 30 Years for Hiding Cameras in Bathrooms
description: The former employee of Royal Caribbean told investigators that he had been secretly recording people, including children, since December 2023.
content: A former employee of the cruise ship company Royal Caribbean was sentenced this week to 30 years in prison for placing hidden cameras in guests’ bathrooms and recording passengers as young as 2, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: “Glitter and doom.” That phrase appears in the subtitle of one of the books we recommend this week (Guy Trebay’s memoir of 1970s New York, “Do Something”), but it also serves nicely as a catchall theme for the list as a whole, which sparkles darkly: a witty horror novel, an exciting debut story collection probing the scarier side of the human psyche, a novel about a man whose unresolved daddy issues leave him at loose ends. In nonfiction, we recommend a group biography of the women who challenged social strictures in 18th-century England (that one’s more glitter than doom), a serious study of the people who helped prop up Hitler and his genocidal reign (more doom than glitter) and a true-crime history about a high-society jewel thief. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: How the Tories Lost Britain
description: Brexit and immigration upended their 14-year reign — setting the stage for a pitched battle to remake British conservatism.
content: Liz Truss has a theory about what caused the collapse of Britain’s Conservative Party, and it has little to do with her. Sitting last May in her corner office across the street from Big Ben, Truss diagnosed the multiple ailments of her party, without referring to her own calamitous, 49-day stint as prime minister. Instead, like the London Eye turning lazily on the far bank of the Thames outside her window, she spun a story about how the Conservatives had drifted away from their ideological moorings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: A Father Found His Son, but a Happy Ending Remains Elusive
description: Shawn Hubler, who covers California for The Times, shares how she balances objectivity with empathy while reporting on homelessness.
content: There are more than 180,000 homeless people in California, and, in June, the Supreme Court ruled that the state could remove those sleeping outdoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Chidgey
title: Beneath a Perfect, Goop-Influenced Exterior Lurks a Violent Past
description: In Chelsea Bieker’s new novel, “Madwoman,” a woman is no longer able to keep the demons of her childhood out of her present.
content: For years Clove has kept her history at bay, marrying a bland but “safe” financier husband and creating the perfect, organic linen-wearing family in Portland, Ore. From sourdough and crystals, bamboo sporks and rainbow chard, she has built a sea wall against her perilous childhood — a violent father, a mother who could not bring herself to leave him, and one shattering day too terrible for Clove to scrutinize. But what happens to a meticulously staged life when the past’s dirty tide threatens to wash away every defense?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Struggling Teenagers Left Out in New Push to Overhaul Reading
description: Districts like New York are revamping elementary school reading instruction. But the middle and high schoolers who don’t read proficiently are an afterthought.
content: American public school districts are rethinking how to teach reading to the youngest children. They have thrown out old lesson plans, retrained teachers and bought new reading programs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron, Maggie Haberman and Eric Schmitt
title: Trump Videos at Arlington Stir More Fallout After Gravesite Visit
description: The family of a Green Beret buried there expressed concern about videos and photos taken by his grave. And a cemetery employee declined to press charges after an altercation with the Trump team, fearing retribution.
content: The family of a Green Beret who died by suicide after serving eight combat tours and is buried at Arlington National Cemetery expressed concern on Wednesday that Donald J. Trump’s campaign had filmed his gravesite without permission as Mr. Trump stood in an area where campaign photography isn’t allowed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ralph Vartabedian
title: How a Real Estate Boom Drove Political Corruption in Los Angeles
description: Prosecutors say that corruption is rising in California cities as one-party rule, inattentive voters and weakened news media have reduced the traditional checks on power.
content: Jose Huizar’s downfall at Los Angeles City Hall was as stunning as his rise to success, a political tragedy that, like many in the land of dreams, has become a familiar one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren and Theodore Schleifer
title: Donors Quietly Push Harris to Drop Tax on Ultrawealthy
description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s fund-raising has benefited from a surge of interest from Silicon Valley and Wall Street.
content: Donors to Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign are pushing her to reconsider supporting a proposed tax on the wealthiest Americans, as some Wall Street and Silicon Valley executives try to reshape the Democratic nominee’s governing agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Dzombak
title: These Architects Embrace Local Styles. And They Fly to Work, Too.
description: Sparrow weavers in Africa appear to learn distinct building styles that reflect group traditions, research shows. It raises intriguing questions about avian intelligence.
content: Birds can be picky building their nests. They experiment with materials, waffle over which twig to use, take them apart and start again. It’s a complex, fiddly process that can seem to reflect careful thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Juliet Macur
title: Flaws Persist in F.B.I.’s Handling of Child Sex Abuse Cases, Watchdog Says
description: The Justice Department’s inspector general cited significant improvements even as he identified structural issues, like high caseloads, that continue to hamper progress.
content: The F.B.I. mishandled child sexual abuse allegations even after enacting new protocols since its bungled investigation into Lawrence G. Nassar’s assault of young gymnasts, the Justice Department’s watchdog found in a report released on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: The Irresistible Urge to Change Your Location on a Dating App
description: Some apps let users check out the dating pool miles away from home. Should they?
content: Maybe the love of your life is just one swipe away — give or take 500 miles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Laber-Warren
title: A ‘Life Review’ Can Be Powerful, at Any Age
description: Reflecting on the past, through writing or conversation, can help us better appreciate where we are — and where we’re going.
content: Jodi Wellman was devastated when her mother died of a heart attack at age 58. Cleaning out her apartment made her feel even worse. Drawers and closets overflowed with abandoned projects: unpublished manuscripts and business cards for ventures that had never gotten started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Maya King
title: Harris, Before CNN Interview Runs, Presses Attack Against Trump in Georgia
description: At a rally in Savannah, the vice president hit her rival over familiar topics like abortion rights and Project 2025, saying he represented a “full-on assault” on basic freedoms.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris, who has spent the last few weeks trying to define herself and her life story for voters, turned on Thursday to describing the version of former President Donald J. Trump that she wants Americans to see, saying his candidacy represented a “full-on assault on hard-fought, hard-won freedoms and rights.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Eric Schmitt
title: F-16 Fighter Jet, Recently Supplied to Ukraine, Crashes
description: A Western official said the advanced fighter crashed while defending against a Russian aerial assault. It was not clear how it was destroyed, but the loss is a blow to Ukraine, given the planes’ prominence.
content: A Ukrainian F-16, recently supplied by NATO countries, was destroyed this week while defending against a sweeping Russian aerial assault and the pilot was killed, Ukraine’s military said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Anna Foley, Caitlin O'Keefe and Jason DeParle
title: The Grocery Bills That May Well Decide the Election
description: The high cost of living is on everyone’s mind, from voters to campaigns.
content: This election, like a lot of elections before it, may come down to which candidate voters think might help them with their grocery bills and housing costs — the essential stuff of everyday economics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Democratic House Candidate Cleared in New York Harassment Inquiry
description: The findings may help the candidate, State Senator John Mannion, in his bid to unseat Representative Brandon Williams in a tossup race.
content: For more than two months, the congressional campaign of John Mannion, perhaps Democrats’ best hope to flip a crucial House seat, has been shadowed by accusations that he created a hostile work environment and berated top aides in the New York State Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! United Canceled Our Trip to Paris. Or Did It?
description: A long-planned French getaway for three hit a snag when their airline reservation was mysteriously canceled, costing them almost $11,000. It turned out an unwanted travel agency was (partially) responsible.
content: Last Oct. 10, my wife, a friend and I arrived at Washington Dulles International Airport to fly to Paris on a trip we had originally planned for April but had to postpone. At the United Airlines check-in counter, agents told us our reservation had been canceled — by us! Even weirder, the same thing had happened three weeks earlier, when the airline sent us an email saying we had canceled our trip. That time, we called and insisted United reissue the reservation for the same price, which it did by giving us a travel voucher and instantly redeeming it. At the airport, though, we watched as supervisors got their supervisors involved, and we were eventually told that something about the voucher had raised questions about fraud. We missed our flight and bought last-minute tickets for that evening’s 11 p.m. United flight to Paris. Then that flight was canceled, though this time for everyone. Given the day’s stress and frustration, we gave up on the trip, had dinner and went to the airport Marriott before heading home the next morning. We believe United owes us for the cost of the last-minute flight ($4,475), a portion of the earlier canceled flight ($3,099), the cost of our transportation, hotel and meals that day ($1,178) and the money we lost on nonrefundable plans in France ($2,007). Can you help? Connie, Towson, Md.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Waterline Breaks Force Grand Canyon to Halt Hotel Stays on South Rim
description: The popular destination has put strict water restrictions into effect before one of summer’s busiest weekends.
content: Citing recent breaks in its waterline, Grand Canyon National Park in northern Arizona announced Wednesday that it would temporarily halt overnight hotel stays on the South Rim of the park starting Thursday afternoon, just before the busy Labor Day weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Betty Jean Hall, Who Fought for Coal-Mining Jobs for Women, Dies at 78
description: She was a fiery lawyer from eastern Kentucky who charged coal companies with discrimination for their refusal to hire women. Her campaign was a success.
content: Betty Jean Hall, a fiery lawyer from the coal fields of eastern Kentucky who brought successful complaints against big coal companies for discriminating against women, paving the way for thousands of them to secure jobs in the industry, died on Aug. 16 in Cary, N.C., near Raleigh. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: At Arlington, Trump Returns to the Politics of the ‘Forever Wars’
description: The 2024 presidential race is the first in 24 years without a major American ground war, but Donald J. Trump continues to stoke division over the post-9/11 conflicts that helped give rise to his movement.
content: Follow along with the latest election updates as Harris and Trump hit the campaign trail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: America Needs Georgia Republicans to Defend Democracy Again
description: A fight over rules to certify elections is part of a long history of efforts to suppress voting rights in the state.
content: Four years ago, it was a Republican official in Georgia, Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, whose refusal to cooperate with Donald Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 presidential election by trying to “find” 11,780 votes helped ensure the integrity of the state’s results, and democracy itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Mogg
title: How to Fend Off Mosquitoes
description: We asked experts how to keep the pests away from your house and protect yourself from bites when you go outdoors.
content: Summer is winding down, but mosquitoes will still be out in full force in early fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Does Alexa Chung Still Have ‘It’?
description: She calls herself a “geriatric ‘it’ girl.” The brand Madewell calls her an “original muse.” Just don’t call this look “indie sleaze.”
content: It was a different world when Alexa Chung rose to sartorial power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: How Dana Bash Handled Past Interviews With Kamala Harris
description: The CNN anchor has been a firm-but-fair interlocutor in three previous interviews with Ms. Harris in the past few years.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris’s interview on Thursday with Dana Bash of CNN is the first major unscripted moment of her young presidential campaign. But it isn’t her first encounter with Ms. Bash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: For a Great Museum Road Trip, Get In an Empire State of Mind
description: Who needs Brooklyn? From Ithaca to Buffalo, the art is overflowing in upstate New York.
content: New York City becomes unspeakably humid. To afford a Sag Harbor quarter-share, you now need an I.M.F. loan. In the Hudson Valley you must do battle with Brooklyn transplants cosplaying locavore Marie-Antoinette.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Trump Should Be Scared — Very Scared — of Debating Kamala Harris
description: If she keeps her cool, he’ll surely lose his.
content: It’s easy to find examples of Vice President Kamala Harris answering questions in a vacuous, speciously thoughtful manner that borders on caricature, and it’s easy to conclude from that oratorical oatmeal that she has delayed a one-on-one sit-down with a serious journalist because she’s not nimble in unscripted situations or fluent in the necessary facts. Those are the Republican talking points, anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicaise Ndembi, Jean Kaseya, Ngashi Ngongo, Tajudeen Raji and Morenike O Folayan
title: The Mpox Crisis Is Much Bigger Than Mpox
description: Throughout Congo and the rest of Africa, it’s society’s most vulnerable who bear the brunt of the mpox outbreak.
content: It is not easy to witness people battling an mpox infection. Fear and stigma make it difficult for patients to seek medical attention soon after symptoms arise, which include a painful rash, fever, muscle aches and sore throat. Misinformation is spreading rapidly. Doctors and other health care workers are straining to fight not just the disease as it afflicts individual patients; they are also up against larger issues they have little control over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Ukraine Says It Struck at 2 Oil Depots Inside Russia
description: Kyiv is pressing its drone campaign while lobbying allies for permission to use weapons supplied by NATO countries for strikes deep inside Russia.
content: Ukraine’s military said on Thursday that it had struck two more Russian oil depots, pressing ahead with a campaign of attacks against a sector vital to Moscow’s war effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Thursday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Pavel Durov, the Russian-born entrepreneur who founded the online communications tool Telegram, was charged yesterday in France with a wide range of crimes and barred from leaving the country. The Paris prosecutor said that Durov was released from custody, but had been ordered to pay bail of five million euros, or about $5.5 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Skye Writing
description: Simeon Seigel sets a course for puzzling adventure.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

title: Attractions and Accessories for the Tennis Obsessed
description: Plus: tableware that channels rural Britain, illustrated pastry boxes and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Clarksville, a historic district of Austin, Texas, has lately emerged as a stylish dining and shopping enclave. Among the area’s most compelling new businesses is La Embajada, a design shop housed in a 1923 Craftsman bungalow. Combining the hospitality and interiors expertise of its founder, Raul Cabra — who has designed tableware for some of Mexico City’s most celebrated restaurants, including Rosetta and Pujol — La Embajada presents a refined, regionally diverse selection of Mexico’s artisanal offerings. A series of small rooms display vintage and contemporary furniture, from stately midcentury armchairs and 1970s glass sconces to a minimalist agave fiber rug by the Oaxaca-based textile artist Trine Ellitsgaard. The house is also an actual residence. Cabra often stays in the bedroom up the creaky stairs, and he’s recently made it available for short-term stays (bookings include a daily basket of baked goods from Austin’s Swedish Hill). Guests can purchase the room’s handmade décor, such as a pair of sleek bedside lamps in milky white onyx, a 1960s La Malinche dresser and a bedspread from a Michoacan manufacturer that once supplied Herman Miller. Downstairs, glassware, candles and gifts fill a section modeled after a typical general store in a small Mexican town. But La Embajada’s heart is its inviting kitchen, where visiting chefs cook elaborate meals and staff prepare ice cream and coffee. In another twist, every bespoke detail — including a hammered copper sink, caramel-colored tiles and waxed pine cabinets — can be custom-ordered for one’s own home. From $295 a night; email queonda@laembajada.shop to inquire about a stay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘The Deliverance’ Review: The Power of Camp Compels Him
description: Lee Daniels directs Andra Day and Glenn Close in an exorcism tale that includes melodrama along with the scares.
content: The director Lee Daniels frees his actors to exorcise their demons with audacious performances that rank among the most memorable of their careers. (If you’ve yet to see the mischief Nicole Kidman gets up to in “The Paperboy,” you’re in for a hoot.) With “The Deliverance,” a riotously wacky horror flick, Daniels adds actual demons, too, sending his latest troubled heroine, Andra Day, straight over the edge. Day, a Grammy-winning musician, earned a Golden Globe Award and an Oscar nomination for her performance in Daniels’s “The United States vs. Billie Holiday.” Not only can she sing and act — here, she’s an outrageous scream queen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: They String the Rackets at the U.S. Open
description: Tennis players rarely break strings anymore, but they still want their rackets to be given a fresh set.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at the people who string rackets at the U.S. Open in Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Ricardo Nagaoka
title: Asian Men Are Finally Starting to Get the Girl (or Guy)
description: Western pop culture, past and present, has often emasculated Asian male characters. A new crop of roles are starting to offer alternatives.
content: It was not long ago that the actor and writer Joel Kim Booster first began going to auditions only to quickly realize that the roles available to him as an Asian American man were severely limited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Author of ‘White Fragility’ Faces Accusations of Plagiarism
description: A complaint filed with the University of Washington raises questions about attribution in Robin DiAngelo’s Ph.D. thesis, which was published 20 years ago.
content: Four years ago, Robin DiAngelo, the author of the best seller “White Fragility,” emerged as a prominent public intellectual and advocate for racial equity and inclusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Movie Trailers Have Gotten Worse. Why Aren’t Studios Having Fun With Them?
description: Promos give away too much or too little or are misleading or don’t leave anything out. We could go on. But there are ways to fix them.
content: I know the trailer for David Fincher’s 2010 drama, “The Social Network,” by heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Wes Moore and the Bronze Star He Claimed but Never Received
description: For years, the Maryland governor has faced questions about whether he had wrongfully said he had a Bronze Star. He insisted no. But an old document proves otherwise.
content: When Wes Moore ran for governor of Maryland in 2022, questions about whether he had claimed to have been awarded a Bronze Star for his Army service in Afghanistan hovered over his campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Here’s What We Know About the Oil Tanker Stuck in the Red Sea
description: The MV Delta Sounion was carrying a million barrels of crude oil when it was attacked by Houthi rebels. On fire and crewless, it now poses an environmental risk.
content: A Greek oil tanker is stuck in the Red Sea after it was attacked by Houthi rebels, an Iran-backed militia group that controls swaths of northern Yemen and has disrupted crucial shipping lanes in a show of solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Google’s Fate
description: We explain the next steps in the Google monopoly case.
content: Google, a judge ruled earlier this month, is a monopolist. Now comes the hard part: How can its search be fixed to restore competition? Next week, the judge will hold his first hearing to consider the answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Separated From Co-Workers, Man Endures Freezing Night in the Rockies Before Rescue
description: Steve Stephanides of Florida stopped to take a break while his colleagues continued up a mountain trail, the authorities said. He got lost on his way back and was found the next day by rescue teams.
content: A Florida man on a corporate retreat became separated from his co-workers during a hike in the Rocky Mountains of Colorado last Friday, leaving him missing in the wilderness for a day and forcing him to brave a bitter storm overnight before being rescued, search and rescue authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Inquiry Into ‘Killer Nurse’ Won’t Weigh Key Question: Is She Innocent?
description: More than 20 experts have called on the U.K. government to delay a public inquiry into the case of Lucy Letby, who was convicted of murdering babies, because of growing concerns about the evidence.
content: A public inquiry into the case of Lucy Letby, a British neonatal nurse convicted of killing seven babies, has come under fire from scientific and medical experts who have called for it to be delayed or broadened to consider whether the deaths could have been caused by other factors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Major Publishers Sue Florida Over Banned School Library Books
description: A state law limits sexual content in school libraries. But several publishing companies say it has led to a “regime of strict censorship” in school districts.
content: Several large American publishers sued Florida education officials on Thursday over a state law that prohibits sexual content in school libraries. They argue that the law has ignited a wave of book removals in violation of the First Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhonda Garelick
title: The Rise of the Husband
description: Much has been made of a new masculinity in this election cycle, but the biggest public transformation for men might be the role of the husband.
content: Given the sudden possibility of electing a female president, there’s been a lot of talk about masculinity of late. It’s true that Democrats have been showcasing genial, outspoken guys who support women’s rights and accomplishments. But beyond the typical male-feminist talking points, there is another, subtler aspect of the new masculinity, which has yet to be acknowledged: husbandliness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Sedona Prince’s Work Off the Court Is Far From Over
description: The basketball player is fighting in a landmark case for college athletes to get paid. She worries a settlement in the suit may not do enough for female and Olympic athletes.
content: Sedona Prince graduated from high school outside Austin, Texas, as an all-American basketball player intent on making her mark. As she enters her final year in college, she has left an indelible imprint — but not on the court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: World Food Program Halts Gaza Aid Deliveries After Workers Are Attacked
description: The U.N. agency said that none of its employees was harmed in the shooting, which occurred Tuesday night near an Israeli military checkpoint.
content: The World Food Program said it is suspending deliveries of aid in Gaza after one of its humanitarian teams was hit by gunfire this week as it approached an Israeli military checkpoint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Yan
title: Want a Manhattan Apartment? Try These European Countries Instead.
description: A study compared the median listing price for a 500-square-foot apartment in Manhattan with the prices of homes in France, Greece, Italy, Portugal and Spain.
content: Americans are already heading to Europe in search of affordable homes, but just how much more space can you get in Europe for the price of a modest Manhattan apartment?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: To Beat Trump, Democrats Seek to Help Anti-Abortion Candidate
description: Randall Terry, a longtime leader in the anti-abortion movement, is running a third-party campaign for president.
content: Some Democratic donors and political operatives have quietly been working to help an anti-abortion activist qualify for the presidential ballot in swing states and assist his campaign, part of an attempt to siphon votes away from the Republican ticket, according to four people with knowledge of the plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Climate Change Comes to the Tetons
description: In one of North America’s most stunning mountain ranges, melting glaciers and warmer temperatures are raising fears of ecological tipping points.
content: On the wall of my hotel room here at the Jackson Lake Lodge in Moran, Wyo., there is a framed photograph of the spectacular Teton Range taken during the 1950s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Eric Adams Calls Himself ‘Dinkins 2.’ Can It Get Him Re-Elected?
description: Mayor Adams is hoping to persuade his base of Black middle-class and older voters that his re-election bid is being undermined just as David Dinkins’s was in 1993.
content: Mayor Eric Adams began his monthly Q. and A. radio program with an unusual self-introduction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz, Michael J. de la Merced and Tripp Mickle
title: Apple and Nvidia in Talks to Invest in OpenAI
description: Led by the investment firm Thrive Capital, the new deal would value the artificial intelligence start-up at over $100 billion.
content: Apple and the chipmaker Nvidia are in talks to invest in OpenAI as part of a new deal that would value the San Francisco artificial intelligence start-up at $100 billion, according to three people familiar with the discussions, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: The Woman Shaking Up German Politics From the East
description: Sahra Wagenknecht, a former Communist, has founded her own party to respond to German grievances about migrants, crime and the dangers of the war in Ukraine.
content: Sahra Wagenknecht, who has never met a political party she could tolerate, has founded her own, and she is shaking up German politics with a combination of right-wing nationalism and left-wing socialism, articulated with seriousness and fluency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Court Orders South Korea to Take Stronger Action on Climate Change
description: A ruling by the Constitutional Court declared the nation’s current measures insufficient and a violation of the rights of future generations.
content: A top South Korean court on Thursday ruled the nation’s measures for fighting climate change insufficient for protecting the rights of citizens, and ordered the government to set firm carbon-reduction targets for 2031 and beyond. It is the first climate litigation ruling of its kind in Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Tim Balk
title: In CNN Interview Excerpts, Harris Defends Ideological Shift to Center
description: Vice President Kamala Harris said it would be “really important” for her administration to reflect “different views,” according to early clips of her interview released by CNN.
content: In her first television interview as the Democratic nominee for president, Vice President Kamala Harris on Thursday defended her ideological shift to the political center, saying she would appoint a Republican to her cabinet but promising “my values have not changed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘The Wasp’ Review: A Feminine Face-Off
description: This twisty psycho-thriller, about two childhood friends reunited under eerily ambiguous circumstances, is above all a dramatic showcase for its stars, Naomie Harris and Natalie Dormer.
content: Actual wasps make multiple appearances in “The Wasp” — a twisty psycho-thriller by the director Guillem Morales — but the big sting comes courtesy of Heather (Naomie Harris, “Moonlight”), a housewife on the edge residing in Bath, England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Wallis and Joann Pai
title: A Driven Introvert Creates His Dream Home in Paris
description: Max Gunawan, a product designer, lost his heart to the Place des Vosges. Now he lives in the fabled square.
content: Timeless with a bit of magic. That is how the company Lumio describes its small line of lamps and speakers that are designed with smart functionality but also a distinct sense of delight. Max Gunawan started Lumio in 2013 with a portable light shaped like a book that turns on when opened and — voilà! — its accordionlike pages form a sculptural fixture that can be used in various tabletop configurations or hung from a strap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Scientists Discover Similar Dinosaur Footprints on Opposite Sides of the Atlantic
description: More than 260 similar footprints found in Brazil and Cameroon help us understand a region that broke apart millions of years ago.
content: They may be an ocean apart, but dinosaur footprints found in South America and Africa are so similar that their discovery suggests dinosaurs may have roamed a narrow corridor that connected the two continents before they split.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Alicia Napierkowski
title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
description: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in Norwalk, Conn., and a six-bedroom in East Setauket, N.Y.
content: A five-bedroom, five-and-a-half-bath, 5,964-square-foot home built in 1964 and renovated and expanded in 2007, with a circular driveway and stone walkway, quarter-sawn oak hardwood floors, crown molding, a sound system, a double-story formal living room with a floor-to-ceiling masonry fireplace, a large formal dining room that steps down into a commercial-grade kitchen, a casual dining area, two first-floor bedrooms, an office, a laundry room, a second-floor en suite primary bedroom with French doors to a private balcony, a lower level with a gym and infrared sauna, a large mudroom with storage and a half bath, and a two-car attached garage with a storage room, on two acres. Jaime Sneddon, 203-219-3769. William Pitt Sotheby’s International, williampitt.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: No Vaccines, Tests or Treatments: Congo Lacks Tools to Confront Mpox
description: The country at the center of a global health emergency is struggling even to diagnose cases and provide basic care.
content: Health officials in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the epicenter of a shape-shifting mpox outbreak, say they lack even the most basic tools necessary to contain and treat the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Meet the Interviewer: CNN’s Dana Bash
description: How Ms. Bash handles Thursday’s interview may play an outsize role in shaping voters’ perception of Kamala Harris.
content: For the second time in barely two months, the CNN anchor Dana Bash is playing a pivotal role in the 2024 presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The Rings of Power’ Season 2, Episode 3: Forging Ahead
description: Arondir is back, along with some other major characters not yet seen this season. And this installment asks: Is Mordor maybe an OK place to live?
content: Amazon released the first three episodes of Season 2 of “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power” at once; read the recaps for Episode 1 here and Episode 2 here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: This Biopic Could Be Angelina Jolie’s Oscar Comeback
description: “Maria,” about the opera diva Maria Callas, plays to the star’s strengths. Its Venice Film Festival debut was timed so the actress could avoid Brad Pitt.
content: She’s one of the most famous actresses to have ever lived, but how formidable is Angelina Jolie’s filmography?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate LoPresti, Frannie Carr Toth, Wendy Dorr, Diane Wong and Jon Pareles
title: Sabrina Carpenter Never Misses Her Target on ‘Short n’ Sweet’
description: The singer’s new album is smart, sly and filled with fury, our critic says.
content: Sabrina Carpenter just released her new album, “Short n’ Sweet.” Though it’s technically her sixth studio album, it’s only her second with full artistic control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna and Tejal Rao
title: The Burger Is a Portrait of America
description: Here are 11 variations that reflect the country’s many facets, and the limitless things a great hamburger can be.
content: One hundred years ago, a teenager named Lionel Sternberger dropped a blanket of American cheese over a hamburger at his father’s sandwich shop in Pasadena, Calif., creating the first cheeseburger. The story may be as flimsy as a Kraft single, but it attests to the decades of tinkering and reinvention that have made the burger a lasting, ever-evolving American genre, like jazz or the Hollywood movie.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 29, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Aug. 29, 2024.
content: A summary for an article on Wednesday about the American tennis player Rajeev Ram and his success in doubles heading into the U.S. Open misidentified his current doubles partner. He is Joe Salisbury of Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The Rings of Power’ Season 2, Episode 2: Strange Weather
description: The Stranger tries his hand again at magic but with mixed results. For now, Sauron does it better.
content: Amazon released the first three episodes of Season 2 of “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power” at once; read the recaps for Episode 1 here and Episode 3 here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Spicy Grilled Shrimp, Grilled Corn With Honeyed Goat Cheese and Peach Upside-Down Cake
description: Who says summer is ending?
content: Labor Day weekend supposedly marks the end of summer, but as I’ve previously grumbled in this newsletter: No, thank you. There will be time enough for heavy sweaters and root vegetables and things cooked in cavernous Dutch ovens. For now, while the sun is setting well past 6 p.m., I want tees and tomatoes and the phrase “hot off the grill.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: University of Virginia Suspends Tours Criticized for Emphasizing Ties to Slavery
description: A group of conservative alumni said the student-led tours were overly focused on the school’s history of using enslaved laborers.
content: The University of Virginia said on Thursday that it had suspended a longstanding campus tour service, but said the move was unrelated to complaints that the tours cast a negative historical spotlight on the school, particularly its relationship to slavery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: ‘Slingshot’ Review: Trapped in Space
description: The paranoia sets in all too quickly in this spare psychological thriller, starring Laurence Fishburne and Casey Affleck.
content: In space no one can hear you scream, and in “Slingshot,” no one can tell you if you’re losing your mind or not. That’s the spare premise of Mikael Hafstrom’s psychological thriller, a film that attempts to graft tropes of the genre onto the inescapable corners of a spaceship, but can’t find the actual parts to make the transfer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: What Is Palestinian Islamic Jihad?
description: The militant group was founded in Gaza in the 1980s, but remains far smaller and holds less sway than Hamas.
content: Israel’s killing of a young commander of the local branch of Palestinian Islamic Jihad in the West Bank city of Tulkarm is shining a spotlight on the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: At Missouri Hearing, Lawyers Spar Over Fate of Prisoner on Death Row
description: The case of Marcellus Williams, 55, who has maintained his innocence in a 1998 killing, has pitted a local prosecutor against the state’s attorney general.
content: In a Missouri prosecutor’s unusual quest to save the life of a man his office once tried to put to death, lawyers called several witnesses to testify in a hearing Wednesday to paint a picture of a murder conviction gone gravely wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: The Highly Deceptive, Deeply Loved, Down-to-Earth Carol Kane
description: Her range is wider than her oddball roles suggest, and the actress adored by Anjelica Huston, Tina Fey and Bette Davis is more connected than you’d think.
content: Do you hear Carol Kane before you see her? The voice that can go pipsqueak high or deep rasp, wavering at just the right moment? Or do you imagine first the mass of golden curls, which telegraph unruliness while actually framing exactly what she wants you to experience?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Prisoner With Parkinson’s Is Executed After Supreme Court Paves the Way
description: The 57-year-old Florida man, convicted in the 1994 killing of a college student, had argued that lethal injection would cause him “needless pain and suffering” because of the disease.
content: A 57-year-old Florida man who had argued that lethal injection would cause “needless pain and suffering” because he has Parkinson’s disease was executed on Thursday evening after the Supreme Court rejected a last-minute request to halt the proceeding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno, Yan Zhuang and John Yoon
title: Tropical Storm Shanshan Drenches Southern Japan, Disrupting Train and Air Travel
description: The storm weakened after making landfall as a typhoon, still posed the risk of landslides and floods as it moved at a crawling speed.
content: Tropical storm Shanshan was drenching southern Japan with record rainfall early Friday, a day after making landfall as a typhoon and flooding towns, knocking out power to tens of thousands of homes, disrupting travel and forcing more than four million evacuations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz and Michael D. Shear
title: With Court Victories, Conservatives Push Back on Biden Policies
description: Legal challenges have blocked many of the policies that President Biden saw as critical to his legacy, on issues like immigration and student loans.
content: After rewriting Title IX regulations to include protections for gender identity, President Biden told trans students: “We see you.” When he announced in April his latest executive actions to waive student loan debt, he proudly proclaimed that “this relief can be life-changing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Israel’s Hostage Rescue Highlights Challenge of Hamas Tunnels in Gaza
description: Gaza’s vast and complex subterranean network shelters many of Hamas’s remaining leaders, and is a key obstacle to eradicating the group.
content: The Israeli military’s rescue of a hostage from an underground tunnel in the Gaza Strip on Tuesday highlighted one of the biggest remaining impediments to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s goal of eradicating Hamas: the enclave’s vast and complicated subterranean network that shelters many of the militant group’s remaining leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: More Than 40 Horses Die on Oklahoma Ranch After Eating Possibly Contaminated Feed
description: Agriculture departments in Oklahoma and Kansas are investigating the deaths on the Beutler ranch, a legacy breeder of livestock that supplies the nation’s rodeos.
content: Dozens of horses on a breeding ranch in Oklahoma that for generations has provided livestock for rodeos were said to have died after eating feed that was contaminated with an additive given to cattle, a veterinarian was quoted as saying, prompting investigations by officials in Oklahoma and Kansas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack and Juan Carlos
title: The High Price of Safety in El Salvador
description: Under President Nayib Bukele, Salvadorans have swapped their rights for quiet streets. How long can that trade-off be maintained?
content: Nöe del Cid watched his neighborhood come back to life from the seat of his wheelchair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Foster Kamer
title: What’s the Deal With the Dare?
description: Harrison Patrick Smith makes bawdy (and sometimes divisive) party music that has New York buzzing — and Charli XCX inviting him to collaborate.
content: In the stairwell of Electric Lady Studios a few weeks ago, Harrison Patrick Smith, 28, was handed a coat hanger carrying an unassuming pair of pants and a T-shirt. “Oh, my street clothes!” he said and laughed, subtly pumping a low fist by his side. “Yes!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Reagan’ Review: The Gipper Takes on Moscow
description: In this unabashed love letter to former president Ronald Reagan, Dennis Quaid fights the Cold War with conviction.
content: In his long career, Dennis Quaid has sometimes played politicians. He’s been former President Bill Clinton (“The Special Relationship”) and was the president in the musical comedy “American Dreamz” with Hugh Grant and Willem Dafoe. Now, in “Reagan,” Quaid portrays former President Ronald Reagan with, if not brilliance, at least evident conviction. Time truly holds surprises for all of us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: 100-Plus Tons of Dead Fish, and Their Smell, Swamp a Greek Port City
description: The mass deaths of the fish were most likely caused by climate change. The vacation area and its businesses have been suffering since.
content: Authorities in central Greece said on Thursday that they had dredged more than 100 tons of dead fish from the waters around the port of Volos, a scenic summer destination, after a mass die-off of fish that is believed to be linked to climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: 30-Year Mortgage Rate Falls Again, Now at 6.35%
description: Further declines could encourage more activity from buyers and sellers.
content: Mortgage rates fell again this week, providing some relief to home buyers and attracting more sellers from the sidelines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Joy Can Do More Than Beat Trump
description: It can push MAGA back to the periphery of American life.
content: There is a difference between beating a candidate and sidelining a movement. After nine years of confronting Donald Trump and facing a MAGA movement that has remade the Republican Party I once belonged to, I believe that fear may be sufficient to beat Trump, but only joy can push MAGA back to the periphery of American life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Zucchini All of the Ways
description: Whether raw with peaches in a salad, seared for cold noodles or caramelized for pasta, now’s the time to go all in.
content: Despite what every “end of summer” Labor Day sale may lead you to believe, summer does not end for another three weeks. No one is going to rip the ice cream cone from your paws or the beach chair from beneath you come Tuesday. But there is one bit of bad news: The window for eating the season’s best produce — the kind people write songs and poems about — is narrowing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley and Anusha Bayya
title: M.T.A. Says No More Free Bus Rides for Fare Evaders
description: Transit officials announced an effort to curb rampant fare evasion on city buses that has cost the agency hundreds of millions of dollars in lost revenue.
content: On Thursday, a group of eight police officers and eight transit workers stood waiting for a crosstown bus on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, some with ticket-writing pads in hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: How Biden’s Senate Allies Helped Push Him From the Race
description: The president’s allies in the chamber he so revered feared he would drag them down and spoil his own legacy, and played a more assertive role than was previously known in his stepping aside.
content: Senator Jack Reed, the West Point graduate, Army veteran and Rhode Island Democrat who leads the Armed Services Committee, is hardly known as a troublemaker prone to rash statements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
title: Telegram Founder’s Indictment Thrusts Encryption Into the Spotlight
description: The criminal charges against Pavel Durov, Telegram’s founder, raised concerns in Silicon Valley about encryption and the app’s approach to privacy and security.
content: When French prosecutors charged Pavel Durov, the chief executive of the messaging app Telegram, with a litany of criminal offenses on Wednesday, one accusation stood out to Silicon Valley companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: How Does Mpox Spread, and Who Is Most at Risk?
description: Here’s what scientists have learned about the virus, which was recently declared a global health emergency.
content: This month, the World Health Organization declared mpox a global health emergency. The virus, formerly known as monkeypox, is spreading quickly in parts of Africa, particularly the Democratic Republic of Congo. The outbreak there has been fueled by a new version of the virus that has also been discovered in Sweden and Thailand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
description: This week’s properties are in Greenwich Village, SoHo and Jackson Heights.
content: An updated one-bedroom, one-bath, roughly 900-square-foot co-op unit with an open floor plan, a windowed kitchen, granite countertops, a breakfast bar, a bedroom with a built-in desk, a windowed marble en suite bath and window-unit air-conditioning, on the 10th floor of a 15-story building with a doorman, an elevator operator, a live-in super, basement storage cages, a wait-listed bike room, shared laundry and a roof deck. Rachel Ostow Lustbader and Rashi Malhotra, Coldwell Banker Warburg, 212-439-5186; cbwarburg.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘1992’ Review: Can They Get Along?
description: The uproar that followed the verdict handed down in the police beating of Rodney King serves as a mere backdrop for fathers and sons to work out their issues in a heist thriller.
content: The Los Angeles riots ultimately amount to little more than a plot device in “1992,” a rote heist thriller that tosses in a double dose of father-son melodrama. Or maybe the paternal bonding has been grafted on to the caper. Either way, nothing in the foreground of this hacky effort, directed by Ariel Vromen, is as interesting as what is happening in the backdrop — which is to say, the verdict handed down in the police beating of Rodney King and its aftermath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Life After Factory Farming: ‘The Longer They’re Out, the Happier They Are.’
description: Tyler Whitley works with a group that helps farmers leave industrialized livestock agriculture, and says consumers can play a role.
content: A few years ago, Tyler Whitley was working at a help line for farmers in financial distress when a call came from a man who was raising poultry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Pelosi’s Car Passed Near Pipe Bomb on Jan. 6, According to New Video
description: As the then-speaker was being evacuated from an overrun Capitol, her security detail drove her near a pipe bomb at the Democratic National Committee headquarters that had yet to be rendered fully safe.
content: As Speaker Nancy Pelosi was evacuated from the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, while the complex was under attack, her motorcade passed by a pipe bomb at the Democratic National Committee headquarters that law enforcement had yet to render safe, according to video and analysis released this week by House Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner and Joan Suazo
title: Honduras Says It Will End Extradition Treaty With United States
description: Honduran leaders, angered after remarks by the U.S. ambassador, said they would terminate the century-old extradition treaty, which was recently used to extradite a former president.
content: Honduras said it would end its longtime extradition treaty with the United States on Wednesday, in response to criticism from the American ambassador to the country over a meeting between Honduran and Venezuelan officials.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Talking Honestly About Feelings of Regret
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about feeling regret about having children. Also: Moved by Gus Walz; Trumpian masculinity; too many choices at Starbucks.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nostrant
title: In Some States, Having a Guardian Means Not Having a Vote
description: More than a million Americans, many with disabilities, live under a court-approved guardianship. Many states block them from voting.
content: When Nicole Noblet’s parents told her they planned to move the family to Missouri to retire, she worried that the move from Minnesota could affect her rights. So she did some research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Harris Sat for Her First Major Interview as a Candidate
description: Also, Israel agreed to pauses in the war for polio vaccinations. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: Kamala Harris and her running mate, Tim Walz, sat down this afternoon with a CNN anchor for an interview that was set to air at 9 p.m. Eastern. It is Harris’s first major television interview since she became the Democratic nominee for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: China Dominates the Situation Room But Not the Campaign Trail
description: The thorny issues raised by America’s most potent geopolitical challenge are reduced to platitudes.
content: Good evening! Tonight, my colleague David Sanger, a White House and national security correspondent, is here with a look at what we are not hearing on the campaign trail about the nation’s biggest geopolitical challenge: China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: This Fall, Choose a Shoe You Can Slip Into
description: Soft, streamlined footwear projects casual cool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Kuras
title: This Is Germany, the Last Country Anyone Wants to Make Great Again
description: The specter of Nazism is haunting the country.
content: Since it became clear that the far-right Alternative for Germany, or AfD, will emerge as a dominant force in eastern Germany’s politics after regional elections this September, I’ve been unable to get a photograph out of my mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta and Justin Porter
title: Friday Briefing: A Defining Harris Interview
description: Plus, a picnic battle on Italy’s beaches.
content: The presidential election is less than 70 days away. This is what we’re watching.

title: ‘The Rings of Power’ Season 2 Premiere: All That Glitters
description: The new season picks up roughly where Season 1 left off — with most of the same strengths and flaws.
content: Amazon released the first three episodes of Season 2 of “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power” at once; read the recaps for Episode 2 here and Episode 3 here.

description: Searching in Clinton Hill and Bedford-Stuyvesant, a young couple endeavored to find a sunny place with a decent kitchen and not too many stairs.
content: Searching in Clinton Hill and Bedford-Stuyvesant, a young couple endeavored to find a sunny place with a decent kitchen and not too many stairs.

description: The subway isn't just buried in the bedrock of New York City — it's embedded within its fiction, too. These archival photographs and literary quotes transport you through time.

author: By McKinnon de Kuyper
title: Tropical Storm Shanshan Brings Extreme Flooding and Travel Delays
description: Tropical storm Shanshan is the strongest storm to hit Japan this year. It has flooded towns, knocked out power and disrupted travel.
content: Tropical storm Shanshan is the strongest storm to hit Japan this year. It has flooded towns, knocked out power and disrupted travel.
